tuv.seg: The 2 types of property ownership in Ireland are leasehold and freehold
Tá dhá cineálacha éagsúla úinéireachta ar réadmhaoine in Éirinn – réadmhaoin ar léas agus réadmhaoin rúilse
Owning the leasehold interest in a property means that you own just the building and not the land it is on and that your ownership is for a fixed number of years

Más le duine réadmhaoin ar léas is ionann sin agus gur leis/léi an foirgneamh amháin agus nach leis/léi an talamh ar a bhfuil sé tógtha agus go bhfuil úinéireacht aige/aici ar feadh méid áirithe blianta socraithe
If you own a leasehold property, you must pay a ground rent to your ground landlord - the person who owns the ground it is built on. The amount of ground rent paid varies
Más leat réadmhaoin ar léas ní mór duit cíos talún a íoc leis an tiarna talún gur leis/léi an talamh ar a bhfuil an foirgneamh tógtha
Often the ground landlord is the local authority
Ní mar a chéile a bhíonn méid an chíosa ar fud na tíre
Owning the freehold interest in a property means that you own the land and buildings (if any) outright
Más leat réadmhaoin rúilse ciallaíonn sin gur leat an talamh agus na foirgnimh (más ann dóibh) ar fad
There is no period of years attached to the ownership and there is no ground rent to pay
Níl aon tréimhse úinéireachta ag baint leis seo. Ní bhaineann cíos talún le réadmhaoin rúilse

When you are buying or selling a property, any ground rent will be recorded on the previous deeds (if the property is registered with the Registry of Deeds) or on the folio (if the property is registered with the Land Registry)

Nuair atá réadmhaoin dhá cheannach nó dhá dhíol agat déanfar aon bunchíos a thaifead ar na gníomhais (má tá an mhaoin cláraithe le Clárlann na nGníomhas) nó ar an bhfóilió (má tá an mhaoin cláraithe ar Clárlann na Talún)
The Property Registration Authority (PRA) controls and manages both the Land Registry and the Registry of Deeds. Read more in our document on property deeds
Is é an tÚdarás Clárúcháin Maoine a dhéanann Clárlann na nGníomhas agus Clárlann na Talún a rialú agus a bhainisteoireacht
The PRA 's Ground Rents Purchase Scheme allows leasehold owners to buy out their ground rent and become outright owners of their property
Tá scéim ag Clárlann na Talún a thugann deis d'úinéirí réadmhaoine ar léas an bunchíos a cheannach amach agus a bheith ina n-úinéirí iomlána ar a maoine

In some circumstances it is not possible to buy out ground rents, if, for instance, it is not in the public interest, or if there is a specific clause in a lease preventing it, but these instances are rare

Tá roinnt cásanna eisceachtúla ann nuair nach féidir bunchíosanna a cheannach amach, mar shampla muna bhfuil sé ar leas an phobail, nó má tá alt faoi leith i léas a chuireann cosc ar seo, ach ní minic a bhíonn na cásanna seo amhlaidh
Buying out your ground rent
Do bhunchíos a cheannach amach
A person who is buying a property may be able to buy out the ground rent once the purchase of the property has been concluded
Nuair atá duine ag ceannach maoine is minic go gceannaíonn sé/sí an bunchíos ag an am céanna
You can buy it either privately or through the Ground Rents Purchase Scheme
Is féidir bunchíos a cheannach go príobháideach agus tríd Scéim Cheannaigh na mBunchíosanna
The amount to be paid when buying out the ground rent can either be agreed between you and the ground landlord (consent procedure) or else obtained through an arbitration procedure

Is féidir leat féin agus an tiarna talún teacht ar réiteach maidir leis an méid atá le n-íoc leis an mbunchíos a cheannach amach nó d'fhéadfaí iarraidh ar eadránaí neamhspléach in oifig Chlárlann na Talún praghas a shocrú

The amount of ground rent is set by the arbitration procedure if you are buying it out under the Ground Rents Purchase Scheme and cannot agree the amount with the ground landlord. The PRA will do all the legal work for a fee

Beidh Clárlann na Talún sásta breathnú i ndiaidh na hoibre dlíthiúil ar chostas, ag brath an bhfuil socrú déanta agaibh féin ar phraghas nó an bhfuil sibh ag iarraidh ar eadránaí Chlárlann na Talún an praghas a shocrú
It is more expensive if an arbitrator is involved - see 'Rates' below
Tá an costas níos mó má bhíonn eadránaí i gceist
If you buy out your ground rent, whether from a private landlord or a local authority, the PRA will issue a Vesting Certificate
Má cheannaíonn tú bunchíos ó thiarna talún príobháideach eiseófar Teastas Dílseacháin
The Vesting Certificate is a new title deed to your property
Tá an éifeacht dlíthiúil chéanna aige seo agus atá ag cáipéis tíolactha agus déanann sé úinéireacht iomlán an áitribh a "dhílsiú" i d'ainm
As such, it is a very important document
(Cineál gníomhais í cáipéis tíolactha.) Is gníomhas teidil do mhaoin nua é an Teastas Dílseacháin

You are strongly advised to have it registered with the Land Registry or the Registry of Deeds, as appropriate, to record the fact that your ownership of the property has changed from leasehold to freehold
Is doiciméad an-tábhachtach é agus molfar duit go tréam do Teastas Dílseacháin a chlárú
If you are buying it out through the arbitration procedure, the fee is €105 for residential owners and €195 for non-residential owners
I gClárlann na nGníomhas coinneofar cóip den cháipéis ar nós gur meabhrúchán a bhí ann. Achoimre ar an gcáipéis é meabhrúchán
